Award.AwardTitle: Workshop/Collaborative Research: NSF Proposal Writing Workshop at 47th SME NAMRC and ASME MSEC; Erie, Pennsylvania; June 10, 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for planning, organization and execution of a proposal-writing workshop to assist young faculty attending joint 47th Society of Manufacturing Engineers North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2019). The attendees will learn how to better frame their research objectives and write competitive proposals to the National Science Foundation. The workshop is designed to engage the NSF academic research community, specifically, young faculty and graduate students aspiring an academic career. Quality proposals result in quality research, knowledgeable faculty and a well-trained workforce. This activity contributes to advanced manufacturing, which is an important sector in the nation's economy. An outcome of the workshop is to identify approaches for successful research and education in support of addressing technological and scientific challenges facing the advanced manufacturing field. The workshop encourages participation of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, early career faculty, and women and under-represented minorities. It stimulates ideas for future directions in research and career paths.

The workshop's overarching objective is to help potential principal investigators write and submit quality proposals to NSF. Participants learn guidelines for writing competitive proposals by communicating clear research objectives. The workshop also fosters partnerships and stimulates meaningful research collaborations among young and established faculty and graduate students. This activity positively impacts the attendees academic career and helps develop the nation's human resources. Well-written proposals result in informed reviews, which are essential to the development of a successful research project. The main activities of the workshop involve presentations by NSF program directors, breakout sessions to discuss example research objectives, a group question/answer period, and a conclusions session. Faculty and graduate students from across the US are invited to participate in the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the proposed proposal-writing workshop was to help young faculty to write more competitive research proposals. The workshop was held concurrently with the 47th Society of Manufacturing Engineers North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2019). The workshop was held at Penn State University at Erie, The Behrend College, on Monday, June 10, 2019, building on the success of previous similar workshops held at the four previous NAMRC/MSEC conferences. The workshop organizers were ZJ Pei (Texas A&M University), George Hazelrigg (George Mason University), and Tony Schmitz (University of Tennessee, Knoxville).

A goal of the workshop was to improve the overall quality of proposals submitted to the National Science Foundation's research programs, particularly in the area of manufacturing research and specifically for proposals that will be submitted to the Advanced Manufacturing cluster. Many young faculty members are in the position of seeking research funding in support of research conducted by them and their students. However, they have received little or no formal training in the art of research proposal writing, and their proposals fail to be competitive. It has been observed that a particular weakness lies in their inability to adequately formulate and express their research objectives and to create a coherent research plan designed specifically to accomplish their stated objectives. This workshop addressed these weaknesses.

The PIs for this workshop have been conducting similar workshops for 15 years and they have observed that attendees get much more out of a proposal writing workshop if they are active participants. Accordingly, the activities of this workshop had a strong focus on participant activities. The workshop included: a working continental breakfast during which the attendees introduced themselves and gave a one-sentence description of their research; a motivational talk covering such things as success rates and their correlation with proposal quality; a writing exercise designed to improve participants' ability to communicate more precisely; lectures on "what is research", "what distinguishes engineering and engineering research from the sciences and mathematics", and "what distinguishes research from development"; a working lunch where attendees formulated an "elevator" speech to describe their research; a lecture on writing an effective Project Summary; a group activity to review the written summaries; and a wrap-up and Q&A session.

Intellectual Merit: The workshop included 31 attendees. Activities included presentations by NSF current and recent Program Directors, a group writing exercise, activities to practice defining research objectives, and a group activity to discuss example project summaries.

Broader Impacts: Professors and graduate students from both the U.S. and other countries attended the workshop. They learned guidelines for writing a quality research objective. Interactions during the workshop with colleagues helped foster meaningful collaborations. The relationships developed during the workshop will positively affect the attendees' academic careers and, subsequently, will help develop the nation's human resources. Additionally, by improving the participants' proposals, the panel reviews will be more consistent. This will help in making the NSF panel review meetings run more smoothly.
